Situation1: They share only one open evening before a busy travel week.
Expectation2: Participate in community service and charity work
Situation2: A monthly food drive for the local homeless shelter is scheduled to take place at the convent today.
Story: I glance at my phone, reading his message: “Can’t wait to see you tonight. Missed you all week.” My heart aches a little. We’ve barely had time together, and with my travel schedule, tonight is our only chance for days. I want to be there, to laugh and talk and just be his girlfriend, not someone always rushing off. But as I set my phone down, the convent bell rings, reminding me of the food drive. The sisters are counting on me; the shelter needs every pair of hands. I picture the faces of the people we help, the gratitude in their eyes. My habit feels heavier than usual, as if it knows I’m torn. I promised him this evening, but I also promised my community I’d serve. My mind spins with guilt and longing—how can I be both the girlfriend he needs and the nun I vowed to be? The clock ticks, and I stand frozen, caught between love and duty, unable to move toward either door.
